author: pipermerriam
content: The designs of Portal fundamentally depend on DHT network topology so that you can map data onto specific parts of the network.  Each piece of content has a location within the DHT keyspace.  This is the mechanism for how data is able to be spread out across the network and still have the data be able to be retrieved.  Does this answer the question adequately?

author: kevaundray
content:
To answer another question in that document I listed, is the workflow you are envisioning this:

- Start up EL + Portal Client
- EL specifies X MB for the portal network
- Portal client will poll the EL for the the latest finalized blocks
- Portal client will seed the history network with whatever finalized block the EL gives them
- EL will delete blocks that are 1 year old -- these should have been in the portal network for a year by now

author: kevaundray
content: If we agree that the external API will not change, then the time to delete historical blocks can be client specific

author: pipermerriam
content:
We already have infrastructure that is responsible for making sure new blocks get into the network, and that if data goes missing from history that it is re-seeded...

So EL implementations *can* choose to do active seeding of data but they don't have to so these two are optional:

> - Portal client will poll the EL for the the latest finalized blocks
> - Portal client will seed the history network with whatever finalized block the EL gives them

author: kevaundray
content:
I think to move forward, there are two things which are needed:

- (Easy) Client devs agree that the methods listed above will not change, wrt their externally observed behaviour after 44444

- Client devs to agree on the path forward to integrating History recovery:
     - Are client devs okay with plugging in the portal client?
     - If not, is this due to the perceived complexity of it, or is it mainly the fact that you are delegating networking/historical block retrieval to another entity?
- Is seeding the network important for client devs or are you happy with just checking that it exists in the portal network and then deleting blocks?

author: pipermerriam
content:
I think the biggest thing I'm excited about here is EL devs learning about the nuances of how Portal works.  There's a massive solution space in DHT networks that we get to take advantage of to solve problems...  I'm confident that in the 2-4 year timeline we'll be able to have competitive fully portal based alternatives for:

- Bulk historical block syncing
- Full syncing of HEAD state
- Full archive node state syncing
- Out-of-protocol state expiry that still allows fast EVM execution while being able to discard most of the state data

We already know how to do all of these things and are simply bottlenecked by how fast we can implement features.

yeah, I need a developer with free time - other than that, it's on the roadmap already - so .. both of the documents have some confusion and some gems in them - I'd look at both as sort of "user stories" that need to be distilled into actionable items. 

this is actually all a lot more simple than it seems, from a client POV: today, there exists a devp2p protocol (eth/6x) for syncing execution client - if an EL implements that protocol fetching the data from portal instead of its own local block store, that node will be indistinguishable from one storing the blocks locally (assuming portal serves the blocks) -> there's an upgrade path in which the users don't even notice this work has been done (specially if they're running validators / consensus clients and not much else)
